subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I agree (the term is minimal pair ). ... You can do that, but it s a lot of painful work.  Using the individual words (as Read does) makes it automatic.
messageBody:
paulhtremblay scripsit:

> I think you argue your point well. In this case, we need to explain
> much of what you say in the FAQ I propose. I doubt most posters on
> this mailing list understand phonomecial pair.

I agree (the term is "minimal pair").

> I think the FAQ would
> point to the dialectical differences, using the IPA. For example,
> Thither would be mapped to ð in most dialects, but to a different one
> in Irish for example.

You can do that, but it's a lot of painful work. Using the individual
words (as Read does) makes it automatic. #6 means the sound of "th"
in "thaw" and "think", however you may pronounce that in your dialect.
Then we just have to explain that in your dialect some things may be
pronounced the same, and then figure out what the general policy
should be in that case (use whichever one you like, or use the one
that matches the distinctions made by TO, or whatever) and explain it.

> It strikes me that you are advocating more or less a more standardized
> way to spell QS. If QS cannot really represent all of the phonomes,

It *can* represent all the phonemes, just not all the *sounds*.

> then we are using it (or so you suggest), in a smilar way to TO. That
> is, though the Irish use a different phonome for 'th', by convention
> we both use the same symbol.

That is what I advocate. However, that is not because Irish English
has a different phoneme, but because it represents the *same* phoneme
with a different sound. The unvoiced dental stop plays the same role
in their dialect as the unvoiced dental fricative does in ours -- it
appears in corresponding places -- because they are just different sound
representations of a single shared phoneme.

Now it's true that not all dialects have exactly the same phonemes.
You merge the three separate sounds that the Southern English use in Ah,
Awe, and Ox into a single phoneme, people in the American South merge
Ah and I, I merge Awe and Ox; many people in the New York-Philadelphia
area have different sounds in "can" (verb) and "can" (noun), making a
new phonemic difference there. But by and large we can get along with
the QS set -- it allows about the right number of distinctions.

--
So that's the tune they play on John Cowan
their fascist banjos, is it? cowan@...
--Great-Souled Sam http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
